feature_description: From initial screening to management, we are here as a digital travel companion that empowers you with intelligent AI support and deep empathy.
screening_description: Start your mental health journey with a smart and adaptive initial screening. Our system uses artificial intelligence to ask questions relevant to your condition, ensuring a personal and efficient screening process. The results of this screening will be the basis for tailored recommendations and action plans.
screening_details: Get an initial understanding of your mental condition through a series of clinically designed questions presented in a comfortable and easy-to-follow conversational format.
analysis_description: Leverage the power of Natural Language Processing (NLP) analysis to dig deeper into your thought patterns and emotional dynamics. Our interactive journal feature helps you reflect on daily experiences, while AI works in the background to detect sentiment, extract key themes, and identify potential cognitive distortions.
analysis_details: Our AI automatically analyzes your journal entries to provide valuable insights into emotional trends, recurring themes in your thoughts, and helps recognize unhelpful thought patterns.
action_plan_description: Based on the results of the screening and in-depth analysis, Mynd creates a personalized action plan just for you. This plan includes recommendations for educational content, evidence-based self-help exercises like Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and mindfulness, and a mood tracker feature to support a structured and sustainable recovery process.
action_plan_details: Access a variety of practical exercises such as CBT techniques to change negative thought patterns, mindfulness exercises to increase self-awareness, and track your mood progress regularly.
education_description: Increase your understanding of mental health through our rich and easily accessible library of educational content. We provide a variety of informative articles, engaging videos, and infographics designed to explain various mental health topics in a comprehensive yet light and easy-to-digest manner.
education_details: Learn more about various mental conditions, stress management strategies, tips for maintaining emotional well-being, and effective ways to combat the negative stigma surrounding mental health.
professional_description: If you need further support, Mynd facilitates you to connect with a network of verified professional psychologists and counselors. We also help prepare a summary of your condition based on the data in the application to facilitate your initial consultation session, so you can get the right help faster.
professional_details: Explore our professional directory, take advantage of the consultation session scheduling feature, and get an automatic summary of your mental health data to share with your chosen professional.
cta_description: Take the first step towards a better understanding of yourself. The initial screening only takes 5-10 minutes.

mindfulness.title: Mindfulness Breathing Exercise
mindfulness.subtitle: Find calm and focus through a simple breathing exercise you can do anywhere, anytime.

whatIs.title: What is Mindfulness Breathing?
whatIs.p1: Mindfulness breathing is the practice of focusing your full attention on the sensation of your breath in the present moment, without judgment. It's not about changing how you breathe, but rather observing the natural process of your breathing.
whatIs.p2: By training your awareness on the breath, you train your mind to be calmer, more focused, and fully present in the current moment.

steps.title: Exercise Steps
steps.subtitle: Follow these simple steps to get started.

1.title: Find a Comfortable Position
1.description: Sit comfortably in a chair with your back straight but shoulders relaxed. You can also lie down if that's more comfortable. Make sure you won't be disturbed for a few minutes.

2.title: Close Your Eyes (Optional)
2.description: Gently close your eyes. If you're not comfortable closing them, just gently lower your gaze downwards, about a meter in front of you, without focusing on anything.

3.title: Observe Your Breath
3.description: Turn your attention to your breath. Feel the sensation of the air entering and leaving your body. Notice where you feel the breath most: maybe in your nostrils, throat, chest, or abdomen.

4.title: Don't Change, Just Observe
4.description: There's no need to change the way you breathe. Let the breath flow naturally. Your only task is to observe, to be a witness to each inhale and exhale.

5.title: Return When the Mind Wanders
5.description: Your mind will inevitably wander – this is completely normal. When you notice your mind is no longer on your breath, acknowledge where it went, and then gently guide your attention back to the sensation of breathing.

6.title: Continue for a Few Minutes
6.description: Start with 3-5 minutes. You can use a timer if you like. Over time, you can increase the duration if you feel comfortable.

7.title: End Gently
7.description: When you're done, take a moment to notice how your body and mind feel. Slowly open your eyes (if they were closed) and carry this awareness into your next activity.

tips.title: Additional Tips
tips.t1: **Consistency is key.** It's better to practice for a few minutes every day than for a long time but infrequently.
tips.t2: **Be gentle with yourself.** There is no 'wrong way' to be mindful. The learning process is part of it.
tips.t3: You can do this exercise **anytime** you feel you need a break or are feeling stressed.

pmr.title: Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) Exercise
pmr.subtitle: Release physical and mental tension with the structured progressive muscle relaxation technique.

whatIs.title: What is Progressive Muscle Relaxation?
whatIs.p1: Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR) is a deep relaxation technique developed by Dr. Edmund Jacobson in the early 20th century. This technique involves a systematic process of tensing specific muscle groups in your body, holding the tension for a moment, and then releasing it.
whatIs.p2: By focusing on the difference in sensation between tension and relaxation, you learn to become more aware of and release physical tension you often don't notice, which in turn can help calm the mind.

benefits.title: Benefits of PMR Exercise
benefits.b2: Helps with insomnia and improves sleep quality.
benefits.b3: Lowers symptoms of anxiety and stress.
benefits.b4: May help reduce certain types of pain (e.g., tension headaches).

guide.title: Progressive Muscle Relaxation Exercise Guide
guide.subtitle: Follow this sequence, focusing on each muscle group.

preparation.title: Preparation Before Starting
preparation.p1: Find a quiet and comfortable place where you won't be disturbed for 15-20 minutes.
preparation.p3: You can sit in a chair that supports your back or lie down.
preparation.p4: Remove your glasses or contact lenses if you wear them.
preparation.p5: Take a few deep, slow breaths to begin.

groups.label: Muscle Group {{index}}
groups.focus: Focus on the difference in sensation between tense and relaxed.

hands.name: Hands and Forearms
hands.instruction: Clench your fists as tightly as you can for 5-7 seconds, feel the tension. Then, release slowly for 10-15 seconds, feeling the relaxation.

upperArms.name: Upper Arms (Biceps)
upperArms.instruction: Flex your arms and tense your biceps (like lifting weights) for 5-7 seconds. Release slowly.

forehead.name: Forehead
forehead.instruction: Raise your eyebrows as high as possible, hold for 5-7 seconds. Release slowly.

eyes.name: Eyes and Cheeks
eyes.instruction: Squeeze your eyes shut as tightly as possible and wrinkle your cheeks for 5-7 seconds. Release slowly.

mouth.name: Mouth and Jaw
mouth.instruction: Open your mouth as wide as possible, or clench your jaw tightly (choose one) for 5-7 seconds. Release slowly.

neck.name: Neck and Shoulders
neck.instruction: Shrug your shoulders up towards your ears as high as possible, hold for 5-7 seconds. Release slowly. Alternatively, tuck your chin to your chest, feeling the stretch in the back of your neck.

chest.name: Chest
chest.instruction: Take a deep breath and hold it, feeling the tension in your chest for 5-7 seconds. Exhale slowly and release the tension.

stomach.name: Stomach
stomach.instruction: Pull your stomach in as tightly as you can, hold for 5-7 seconds. Release slowly.

back.name: Back
back.instruction: Arch your back slightly (if comfortable), hold for 5-7 seconds. Release slowly.

thighs.name: Thighs
thighs.instruction: Tighten your thigh muscles as hard as you can for 5-7 seconds. Release slowly.

calves.name: Calves
calves.instruction: Point your toes upwards (towards your knees) to tense your calf muscles, hold for 5-7 seconds. Release slowly.

feet.name: Feet and Toes
feet.instruction: Curl your toes downwards as tightly as possible, hold for 5-7 seconds. Release slowly.

after.title: After Finishing
after.description: After completing all muscle groups, enjoy the feeling of total relaxation for a few minutes. Notice how your body feels lighter and your mind calmer. Open your eyes slowly and return to your activities feeling refreshed.

tips.title: Important Tips
tips.t1: Don't hold your breath while tensing muscles; continue to breathe normally.
tips.t2: Tense the muscles just enough, not to the point of pain.
tips.t3: If you have any medical conditions or injuries, consult a doctor before trying this exercise.
tips.t4: Practice regularly to get the maximum benefit.

warning.title: Caution
warning.description: This exercise is intended for general relaxation. If you experience chronic pain, severe tension, or other medical conditions, always consult with a healthcare professional before starting a new exercise program.

anxietyArticle.title: Managing Anxiety: A Guide to Peace of Mind
anxietyArticle.subtitle: Understand what anxiety is, recognize its symptoms, and learn effective strategies to manage it in daily life.

understanding.title: Understanding Anxiety
understanding.p1: Anxiety is the body's natural response to stress or potential danger. It's an emotion characterized by feelings of tension, worried thoughts, and physical changes like increased heart rate or sweating. To a certain extent, anxiety can be beneficial, for example, motivating us to prepare for an exam or an important presentation.
understanding.p2: However, when feelings of anxiety become excessive, occur too frequently, or are disproportionate to the situation, it can interfere with quality of life and be categorized as an anxiety disorder. It's important to recognize the difference.

symptoms.title: Recognizing the Symptoms of Anxiety
symptoms.description: Anxiety symptoms can vary from person to person, but they generally include physical, cognitive, and behavioral aspects.

physical.title: Physical Symptoms:
physical.s4: Dry mouth, nausea, or digestive issues

cognitive.title: Cognitive Symptoms:
cognitive.s1: Excessive worry about the past, present, or future
cognitive.s2: Negative or pessimistic thoughts that are hard to control
cognitive.s3: Difficulty concentrating or mind going blank
cognitive.s4: Feeling like you're about to lose control or go crazy

relaxation.title: Relaxation Techniques
relaxation.p3: can help calm the physical response to anxiety.

mindset.title: Healthy Mindset (CBT Basics)
mindset.p1: Identify and challenge negative or unrealistic thoughts that trigger anxiety. Replace them with more balanced and positive thoughts. Learn more about the

lifestyle.title: Healthy Lifestyle
lifestyle.l1: Regular exercise can release endorphins and reduce tension.
lifestyle.l2: Sufficient and quality sleep is crucial for mental health.
lifestyle.l3: Eat a balanced, nutritious diet and limit caffeine and alcohol.

social.title: Seek Social Support
social.p1: Talking to friends, family, or joining a support group can help you feel less alone and gain new perspectives.

professionalHelp.title: When to Seek Professional Help?
professionalHelp.description: If your anxiety is severe, long-lasting, significantly disrupts your daily activities, or if you start having thoughts of self-harm, it is crucial to seek help immediately from a mental health professional such as a psychologist or psychiatrist. They can provide a proper diagnosis and a suitable treatment plan.

cbtArticle.title: Introduction to Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)
cbtArticle.subtitle: Understand the basics of CBT, how it works, and how it can help you change your thought patterns and behaviors.

whatIs.title: What is Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)?
whatIs.p1: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is a type of psychological therapy (psychotherapy) that has been proven effective for a variety of mental health issues, including depression, anxiety disorders, substance use problems, eating disorders, and relationship problems.
whatIs.p2: CBT is based on the idea that our thoughts, feelings, physical sensations, and actions are interconnected. Negative thoughts and feelings can trap us in a vicious cycle. CBT aims to help you break this cycle by identifying and changing negative or unhelpful thinking patterns (cognitions) and behaviors.

principles.title: Core Principles of CBT
principles.p1: **Focus on the Present:** CBT focuses more on present-day problems and solutions rather than extensively digging into the past.
principles.p2: **Structured and Goal-Oriented:** CBT sessions are typically structured, with a clear agenda and goals agreed upon by both the therapist and client.
principles.p3: **Collaborative:** The therapist and client work together as a team to understand problems and develop strategies.
principles.p4: **Teaches Skills:** CBT aims to equip you with practical skills that you can use in your daily life to cope with challenges.
principles.p5: **Evidence-Based:** The effectiveness of CBT is supported by a large body of scientific research.

howItWorks.title: How CBT Works: The Cognitive Model
howItWorks.p1: CBT is based on the cognitive model, which posits that it's not the situation itself that determines how we feel, but rather how we interpret or think about the situation.
howItWorks.model: Situation → Automatic Thought → Reaction (Emotion, Behavior, Physical Sensation)
howItWorks.example: For example: Imagine you weren't invited to an event by a friend.
howItWorks.thought: "They don't like me," "I must be boring."
howItWorks.p2: CBT helps you identify these negative automatic thoughts, evaluate their accuracy, and replace them with more realistic and helpful ones.
howItWorks.altThought: "Maybe they forgot, or it was just a small group event. I can ask them about it nicely or plan something else with them another time."

issues.p1: CBT is effective for a wide range of conditions, including:

techniques.title: Simple CBT Techniques
techniques.p1: Here are some basic techniques often used in CBT:

t1.title: 1. Thought Record
t1.description: Writing down a situation, the automatic thoughts that arise, the emotions felt, and then trying to formulate a more balanced, alternative response.

t2.title: 2. Cognitive Restructuring
t2.description: Identifying cognitive distortions (inaccurate negative thought patterns, like overgeneralization or catastrophizing) and learning to challenge and change them.

t3.title: 3. Behavioral Activation
t3.description: Encouraging participation in activities that are enjoyable or provide a sense of accomplishment, especially to combat depression and withdrawal.

t4.title: 4. Graded Exposure
t4.description: Gradually and systematically confronting feared situations or objects to reduce anxiety and phobias.

journey.title: CBT is a Collaborative Journey
journey.description: While this article provides an introduction, CBT is most effective when done with the guidance of a trained therapist. A therapist can help you apply these techniques in a personalized and in-depth way. If you feel you need support, don't hesitate to seek a professional.
